dt: {bc}to gain or acquire by force of arms {bc}{sx|subjugate||}
{bc}to gain {d_link|mastery|mastery} over or win by overcoming obstacles or opposition
{bc}to overcome by mental or moral power {bc}{sx|surmount||}

pt: {sc}conquer{/sc} {sc}vanquish{/sc} {sc}defeat{/sc} {sc}subdue{/sc} {sc}reduce{/sc} {sc}overcome{/sc} {sc}overthrow{/sc} mean to get the better of by force or strategy. {sc}conquer{/sc} implies gaining mastery of.

pt.t: {it}vanquished{/it} the enemy and ended the war

pt: {sc}defeat{/sc} does not imply the finality or completeness of {sc}vanquish{/sc} which it otherwise equals.

pt.t: the Confederates {it}defeated{/it} the Union forces at Manassas
{it}subdued{/it} the native tribes after years of fighting

pt: {sc}reduce{/sc} implies a forcing to capitulate or surrender.

pt.t: the city was {it}reduced{/it} after a month-long siege

pt: {sc}overcome{/sc} suggests getting the better of with difficulty or after hard struggle.
{sc}overthrow{/sc} stresses the bringing down or destruction of existing power.

quotes.t: But however vile the movie, the sentiments it embodies are (as they say) American as apple pie: the west was something to be {qword}conquered{/qword} and claimed.

And my girlfriends are really strong, feminine women—yet we can all be girls together. Some days we just have to go out and shop, get a massage …  . The next day we want to {qword}conquer{/qword} the world and start our own company.
It used to be that men "{qword}conquered{/qword}" mountains in a cacophony of gratuitous chest-thumping.
After her initial passionate prayer of thanks for the strength to {qword}conquer{/qword} her vast disappointment, she stayed on her knees, the hassock comfortable …

et: Middle English, to acquire, conquer, from Anglo-French {it}conquerre{/it}, from Vulgar Latin {it}*conquaerere{/it}, alteration of Latin {it}conquirere{/it} to search for, collect, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}quaerere{/it} to ask, search
shortdef: to gain or acquire by force of arms : subjugate
to overcome by force of arms : vanquish
to gain mastery over or win by overcoming obstacles or opposition

dt: {bc}to make a group of people disagree and fight with one another so that they will not join together against one

dt.t: His military strategy is to {it}divide and conquer{/it}.

shortdef: to make a group of people disagree and fight with one another so that they will not join together against one
